III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
Section (1) An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
Description parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
1

(a) A plan of visitation for each child in foster care consistent
with the child’s service plans, as required by R 400.12419 and R
400.12420 to assure the safety and well-being of the child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There is a concern that a child placed in care has been exposed
to a convicted child abuser and the agency has not properly
addressed it. The child was reported to be in bed with the
convicted child abuser.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on May 8, 2023.
Complainant stated he became aware a man with criminal history
involving children had been around Youth A during unsupervised
parenting time with Parent 1. Complainant stated he reported it to
Foster Care Worker (FCW) and was told he is not able to be given
information regarding Parent 1’s case and advised him to contact
his attorney and Child Protective Services if he has further
concerns.
Complainant 2 was contacted via text message on May 15,
2023. Complainant 2 was advised that DCWL is involved to review
compliance with licensing rules. She was provided guidance to
contact Child Protective Services for any child safety concerns as
well as Youth A’s guardian ad litem.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via telephone on
May 9, 2023. CA stated this is an emotional case due to a child
death before the agency became assigned. The relationship
between Parent 1 and Parent 2 is very contentious and Parent 2 is
upset because Parent 1 has recently progressed to unsupervised
visits 1 day per week with Youth A. Parent 2 has been verbally
aggressive towards FCW directly and on social media. The
agency was already aware of the allegations. As a result of the
allegations FCW had a straightforward conversation with Parent 1
and reviewed a safety plan regarding the unsupervised parenting
time. CA stated her understanding is Youth A does not formalize
words the way it was stated in the allegation.
Foster Care supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on May 9, 2023. There have been ongoing issues
between Parent 1 and Parent 2, but the issues began to escalate
when Parent 1 progressed in her treatment plan and moved to
unsupervised parenting time. FC supervisor stated Parent 2 is
concerned with Parent 1’s ability to parent Youth A. She stated
Parent 2 reported to herself and FCW concerns regarding Parent
1’s new boyfriend and his criminal history involving children. FCW
2

followed up on the concerns with Parent 1 who advised she is no
longer in contact with the individual and he was never in her home
or around Youth A. FC supervisor stated Parent 2 continued to
demand the agency do random visits to Parent 1’s home. FC
supervisor stated she tried to reassure Parent 2 the agency would
follow up on the information, but Parent 2 continued to become
upset and has been verbally aggressive towards FCW and
threatened to contact media outlets.
FC supervisor stated a TDM was held prior to Parent 1
transitioning to unsupervised parenting time. The agency has
followed up with Parent 1 anytime concerns were reported. The
agency developed a safety plan that Parent 1 agreed to and
signed. The safety plan included no individuals present during
unsupervised parenting time without prior approval from the
agency.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
May 10, 2023. FCW stated Youth A entered foster care after a
child death occurred involving her older sibling. The alleged
perpetrator was Parent 1’s boyfriend at the time. A treatment plan
was ordered for Parent 1 and Parent 2 following the removal of
Youth A. Parent 1 has been progressing with her treatment plan.
The agency began unsupervised parenting time for day visits in
January and recently moved to one overnight visit per week
approximately one month ago. FCW stated Parent 2 started to
escalate when the unsupervised parenting time started because
he doesn’t want Youth A to be returned to Parent 1. FCW stated a
week or two ago Parent 2 informed FCW about Parent 1’s current
boyfriend. Upon receipt of the information FCW contacted Parent
1. Parent 1 stated she spoke to the individual and went on a
couple dates, but she doesn’t know him very well and he has
never been to her home or around Youth A. FCW stated she
advised Parent 1 of his Child Protective Services history. Parent 1
stated to FCW that she has cut off communication with him. FCW
stated she conducted an unannounced home visit with Parent 1
during an unsupervised parenting time after receiving the
concerns from Parent 2. FCW stated there is no evidence that
anyone else is residing there. FCW stated Youth A has limited
verbal skills due to her age. She is just starting to put more words
together but is difficult to understand but does not have complete
sentences based on her observations. FCW stated the allegations
of Youth A’s statements do not match her verbal skills.
FCW stated the agency has a protocol they follow when a parent
begins unsupervised parenting time. A TDM was held prior to the
3

start of unsupervised visits. During the TDM a safety plan was
reviewed that includes no individuals during parenting time that
were not approved to be present by the agency prior to the visit,
valid driver’s license, active car insurance and appropriate car
seat, emergency contact list in the event of an emergency, and no
substance use in the present of the child. FCW stated the safety
plan was again reviewed with Parent 1 upon receipt of the current
concerns. FCW stated she has not received concerns from
anyone other than Parent 2 and Youth A’s current caregiver,
Parent 2’s mother.
Documents reviewed:
 Team Decision Making (TDM) report dated November 10,
2022. Discussion around unsupervised parenting time
starting for Parent 1 in December after parenting coach
services end. Safety plan discussion included visits will only
include Parent 1 and Youth A. Any additional person must
receive a clearance prior.
 December 12, 2022, SWC states FCW informed Parent 1
via text message that unsupervised parenting time will
begin on January 5, 2023. FCW reminded Parent 1 that
parenting time is only between her and Youth A. In
addition, no smoking or alcohol use is permitted while
Youth A is in her care. Any violation of the safety plan will
result in visits going back to supervised.
 May 5, 2023, SWC states FCW made an unannounced visit
to home of Parent 1 during unsupervised visit with Youth A.
FCW met with Youth A alone and she made no mention of
Parent 1’s boyfriend. FCW notes there was no evidence
anyone else was residing in the apartment other than
Parent 1. A safety plan was presented to Parent 1 that
stated she agreed not to allow anyone else to be present
during parenting time without approval of the agency.
Parent 1 agreed and signed it.
 Safety plan dated May 5, 2023, states, in part, the parent
will not allow visitors at the visit, except when approved by
the agency. The parent/child visits are for attachment and
bonding between the parent and child. Safety plan signed
and dated by Parent 1.
 December 14, 2022, court order states Parent 1 shall have
unsupervised visits with discretion for unsupervised
overnight visits with GAL approval. March 10, 2023, court
order states parenting time for Parent 1 is unsupervised
until further order of the court, DHS/designee.
4

Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file the
agency is providing unsupervised parenting time between Parent
1 and Youth A that is consistent with Youth A’s service plan, most
recent court orders, and have taken appropriate steps to assure
the safety and well-being of Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
